Award.AwardTitle: Teaching and Learning Algebraic Thinking Across the Middle Grades: A Research-based Approach Using PhET Interactive Simulations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Widespread, high-quality use of technology has great potential to transform today's mathematics classrooms and enable all students to develop a robust conceptual understanding of mathematics. Critical challenges are currently limiting the realization of this potential, and 69% of US Grade 8 students are scoring below proficient in national studies. In this 3-year Discovery Research K-12 Full Research and Development project, Teaching and Learning Algebraic Thinking Across the Middle Grades: A Research-based Approach Using PhET Interactive Simulations, the PhET Interactive Simulations group at the University of Colorado Boulder is partnering with mathematics education researchers at the University of South Florida St. Petersberg and Florida State University to address three central challenges, as follows: 1) the tendency for students to not engage in real mathematical thinking as they use technologies; 2) the tendency for teachers to not enact pedagogically-effective approaches; and 3) the lack of adoption of effective technologies by teachers due to a variety of barriers. This collaborative effort uses rich, exploratory, interactive simulations and associated instructional materials as a pathway for making rapid progress and focuses on advancing algebraic thinking in Grades 6-9.

This project seeks to enable teachers to fully-leverage the benefits of interactive simulations to advance student engagement and learning of mathematics, moving technology from the margins to a core part of instruction. The project will answer critical research questions, such as: how the design of an interactive simulation can generate pedagogically-productive use; how instruction with simulations can be best structured to support learning of mathematical concepts and engagement in mathematical practices; how sim-based instruction can be made attractive, feasible and effective for teachers; and finally, how student learning is impacted by sim-based instruction. At the same time, this project will produce a collection of open educational resources for teachers and students. These resources will include 15 research-based, student-tested simulations for teaching and learning of algebraic thinking, associated instructional support materials, and teacher professional development resources for effective implementation. Based on the 75 million uses per year of PhET?s science simulations, we expect these resources to transform mathematics instruction for millions of students and thousands of teachers.

This project will employ a variety of research methods to approach these questions. Researchers will use individual interviews from a diverse group of Grades 6-9 students as they use the 15 new simulations to examine usability, engagement, and achievement and to identify design approaches that stimulate productive use. In parallel, classroom-based studies in Colorado and Florida will investigate ways in which simulations can be combined with instructional materials and teacher facilitation to engage groups of students in inquiry, promote rich discussions of important mathematical ideas, and advance achievement in the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics. The project will employ an iterative design and development process involving qualitative and quantitative analysis of diverse measures including the quality of mathematical instruction. Finally, a pilot study and an evaluation of teacher PD supports will examine the feasibility and fidelity with which teachers implement the innovation, and the impact on student learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PhET Interactive Simulations is an educational technology research and development group at University of Colorado Boulder. The PhET group has conducted research on simulation design and development, and teaching and learning with simulations since 2002, while also disseminating a suite of free high-quality interactive simulations and associated teacher resources to advance STEM learning around the world. The full suite of PhET resources includes over 160 free and openly-licensed interactive simulations with associated teaching resources, and an open source technical infrastructure for interactive learning resources. The simulations are run more than 200 million times per year worldwide, across K-16 levels, and have been translated into 90 languages.

   Through NSF DRL-1503510 Teaching and Learning Algebraic Thinking Across the Middle Grades: A Research-based Approach Using PhET Interactive Simulations, the PhET group partnered with mathematics education researchers at CU Boulder, Florida State University, and University of South Florida St. Petersburg to address critical challenges limiting the attainment of truly transformative, widespread, high-quality use of technology in today's mathematics classrooms. We proposed that rich, exploratory, interactive simulations and associated instructional materials were promising pathways for making rapid progress on addressing these challenges, including 1) the tendency for students to not engage in real mathematical thinking as they use technologies; 2) the tendency for mathematics teachers to not enact pedagogically-effective approaches when using technology; and 3) the lack of adoption of effective technologies by mathematics teachers due to a variety of barriers. 

   Working with middle grades mathematics teachers, researchers, and simulation design experts, we designed and developed 17 high-quality, interactive simulations covering concepts central to developing algebraic thinking, such as proportional reasoning, equality, making connections between representations, and generalization of patterns using expressions and functions. Each simulation presents learners with an open exploratory environment that is interactive and dynamic, includes multiple, linked representations, and supports rapid inquiry cycles. Implicit scaffolding within the simulation is employed to create environments in which students have significant agency and are inclined to explore and interact in productive ways. All simulations address Common Core State Standards for Mathematics. Example simulations include Function Builder, Equality Explorer, Area Model Algebra, Number Line: Integers, and Expression Exchange.

   These interactive simulations present mathematics teachers with new opportunities to create student-centered classroom environments. Classroom research focused on examining 1) how teachers positioned simulations in their instruction, 2) how teachers' use of simulations transformed their facilitation of student learning, and 3) how teaching with simulations impacted teachers' ideas about teaching, student capabilities, and the nature of mathematics. 

   Our analysis of teachers' simulation-based mathematical lessons found that teachers' positioning of simulations varied, from merely supplementing teacher-led presentation to driving mathematics learning through innovative perspectives and student-centered tasks. We identified 5 different sim-to-student relationships enacted in the classroom, such as 'simulation as a source of information with students as recorders' or 'simulation as a playground with students as explorers'. 

  Our research demonstrated that teacher use of simulations transformed the mathematics classroom and student experience. In comparing teacher enactment of sim-based and non-sim lessons, we found that when teachers employed simulations they used more student-centered teaching practices. In sim-based lessons, teachers created more opportunity for student voice and agency and classroom norms focused on exploring mathematical ideas, inventing strategies, and sharing ideas. In non-sim lessons, teachers focused more on practicing procedures, recalling facts, and appealing to rules. Our video analysis of sim-based lessons using the Mathematical Quality of Instruction protocol indicated higher cognitive demand, students communicating their ideas productively, and greater use of mathematical practices. 

   We also observed shifts in teachers' ideas about teaching, student capabilities, and the nature of mathematics when using simulations. In a case study, for instance, a teacher, when referring to her non-sim lessons, framed pedagogical problems as problems that occured with students (e.g. students not motivated). When referring to sim-based lessons, she framed pedagogical problems as puzzles of teaching practice. Additionally, she described low-achieving students as more capable of engaging in high-level thinking and contributing to classroom discussion, when she described her sim-based lessons.

   Broad teacher adoption of mathematics simulations is supported with a variety of instructional resources, including sim-specific teacher tips, over 40 sim-based lessons, and an on-demand virtual workshop for mathematics teachers. Evaluation surveys demonstrated that teachers have favorable views and experiences with simulations; teacher respondents report positive impacts for students' conceptual understanding (99%), engagement (96%), and attitudes toward math (92%). Teachers report high engagement for low-, middle-, and high-achieving students, suggesting that simulations are a promising tool for equitable mathematics instruction. 

   The project team further disseminated the research findings and knowledge generated to teacher, education technology, and education research communities through: 11 publications; three PhD theses; 42 conference presentations; 2 NSF "STEM For All" video showcase videos; and social media channels. 

   Overall, outcomes of this project are serving to transform the way mathematics is taught and learned at the middle school level.
